cards.headline: Top 10 VS Code Extensions to boost productivity

sheets.title: Live Server
sheets.summary: You get a local development server for HTML.
sheets.description: Automatically refreshes your browser to view code changes in real-time, ideal for static HTML development.

sheets.title: Tabnine
sheets.summary: You'll experience auto-complete, suggestion, and code block generation.
sheets.description: This AI-powered extension helps you code faster by auto-completing code and generating code blocks based on natural language comments.

sheets.title: Colorize
sheets.summary: Visualize CSS colors in your files.
sheets.description: Generates colored backgrounds for variables holding colors, helping you visualize colors in your code.

sheets.title: Prettier - Code Formatter
sheets.summary: Who doesn't like well-formatted code?
sheets.description: This extension helps you format code to match common coding styles, supporting multiple languages for cleaner and consistent code.

sheets.title: GitLens
sheets.summary: You'll enhance Git capabilities within VS Code.
sheets.description: Gain a deeper understanding of code changes and contributors through in-editor annotations, history, comparisons, and Git functionalities.

sheets.title: Path Intellisense
sheets.summary: You'll experience file path autocompletion.
sheets.description: Autocompletes file paths while coding, improving efficiency and reducing errors.

sheets.title: ES7 React/Redux/GraphQL/React-Native snippets
sheets.summary: Generate boilerplate code with fewer keystrokes.
sheets.description: Provides snippets to generate base code quickly, allowing you to focus more on functionality than boilerplate.

sheets.title: Todo Tree
sheets.summary: Locate, list, and track your TODO comments.
sheets.description: Displays TODO comments in a tree view, making it easy for you to navigate and track tasks within your code.

sheets.title: Import Cost
sheets.summary: Know your bundle size while coding.
sheets.description: Calculates the size of imports and requires in your code editor, helping you control the bundle size early in development.

sheets.title: TailwindCSS Intellisense
sheets.summary: A must-have extension for devs using Tailwind CSS.
sheets.description: Enhances your Tailwind development experience by providing autocomplete, syntax highlighting, and linting in VS Code.

cards.headline: Top 10 Git Commands Every Developer Should Know

sheets.title: git init
sheets.summary: Initialize a new Git repository.
sheets.description: Creates a new local Git repository in the current directory, enabling version control for your project. Example: git init my-project

sheets.title: git clone
sheets.summary: Clone an existing Git repository.
sheets.description: Copies a Git repository from a remote source to your local machine, allowing you to work on the project locally. Example: git clone https://github.com/user/repo.git

sheets.title: git add
sheets.summary: Stage changes for commit.
sheets.description: Adds changes in the working directory to the staging area, preparing them to be included in the next commit. Example: git add .

sheets.title: git commit
sheets.summary: Commit staged changes to the repository.
sheets.description: Records changes from the staging area to the Git repository, creating a new commit with a unique identifier. Example: git commit -m 'Add new feature'

sheets.title: git push
sheets.summary: Upload local commits to a remote repository.
sheets.description: Transfers committed changes from your local repository to a remote repository, typically hosted on platforms like GitHub or GitLab. Example: git push origin main

sheets.title: git pull
sheets.summary: Fetch and merge changes from a remote repository.
sheets.description: Fetches changes from a remote repository and merges them into the current branch of your local repository, updating your codebase. Example: git pull origin main

sheets.title: git branch
sheets.summary: Manage branches in the repository.
sheets.description: Lists, creates, or deletes branches within the Git repository, allowing you to work on different features or versions independently. Example: git branch feature-branch

sheets.title: git checkout
sheets.summary: Switch between branches or restore files.
sheets.description: Moves the HEAD pointer to a specified branch or restores files to a previous state, enabling you to work on different parts of your project. Example: git checkout main

sheets.title: git merge
sheets.summary: Merge changes from one branch into another.
sheets.description: Combines changes from one branch into another branch, integrating new features or bug fixes into the main codebase. Example: git merge feature-branch

sheets.title: git stash
sheets.summary: Temporarily store changes for later use.
sheets.description: Saves modified or untracked files in a 'stash' and reverts the working directory to the last commit, useful for switching tasks or fixing urgent issues. Example: git stash

sheets.title: Ctrl + P / Cmd + P
sheets.summary: Quickly open files or search within the project.
sheets.description: Use Ctrl + P on Windows or Cmd + P on Mac to quickly open files or search for files within the project, speeding up navigation and file access.

sheets.title: Ctrl + K + C / Cmd + K + C
sheets.summary: Toggle comment for selected code.
sheets.description: Toggle comments on or off for selected code using Ctrl + K + C on Windows or Cmd + K + C on Mac, improving code readability and organization.

sheets.title: Ctrl + K + U / Cmd + K + U
sheets.summary: Toggle uncomment for selected code.
sheets.description: Toggle uncommenting selected code using Ctrl + K + U on Windows or Cmd + K + U on Mac, simplifying code modification and debugging.

sheets.title: Ctrl + Shift + P / Cmd + Shift + P
sheets.summary: Open Command Palette for various actions.
sheets.description: Open the Command Palette with Ctrl + Shift + P on Windows or Cmd + Shift + P on Mac to access a wide range of commands and actions, enhancing workflow efficiency.

sheets.title: Ctrl + Shift + O / Cmd + Shift + O
sheets.summary: Quickly navigate to symbols within the project.
sheets.description: Use Ctrl + Shift + O on Windows or Cmd + Shift + O on Mac to quickly navigate to symbols (functions, classes, etc.) within the project, improving code navigation and understanding.

sheets.title: Ctrl + K + S / Cmd + K + S
sheets.summary: Save all open files.
sheets.description: Save all open files simultaneously with Ctrl + K + S on Windows or Cmd + K + S on Mac, ensuring all changes are saved without manually saving each file.

sheets.title: Ctrl + Shift + L / Cmd + Shift + L
sheets.summary: Select all occurrences of current word for multi-cursor editing.
sheets.description: Select all occurrences of the current word for multi-cursor editing with Ctrl + Shift + L on Windows or Cmd + Shift + L on Mac, enhancing efficiency in making bulk changes.

sheets.title: Ctrl + Shift + F / Cmd + Shift + F
sheets.summary: Open Search (Find in Files) view.
sheets.description: Open the Search (Find in Files) view with Ctrl + Shift + F on Windows or Cmd + Shift + F on Mac, facilitating efficient searching and replacing within the project.

sheets.title: Ctrl + J / Cmd + J
sheets.summary: Toggle visibility of the Integrated Terminal.
sheets.description: Toggle the visibility of the Integrated Terminal with Ctrl + J on Windows or Cmd + J on Mac, enabling quick access to the terminal for commands and scripts.

sheets.title: Ctrl + D / Cmd + D
sheets.summary: Add next occurrence to multi-cursor selection.
sheets.description: Use Ctrl + D on Windows or Cmd + D on Mac to add the next occurrence of the current word to the multi-cursor selection, streamlining editing tasks and code modifications.

sheets.title: Fn + F2
sheets.summary: Rename symbol or identifier.
sheets.description: Use Fn + F2 to quickly rename symbols or identifiers across your codebase, improving code maintainability and readability.
